--- title: "Collatz" author: "Pierre Casadebaig" date: "2021-06-01" categories: [generative] image: "img/preview.png" format: html lightbox: true --- > ### Curves parameterized from integer sequences and positioned according to basic botanical rules. This system focuses on a very simple generator, here a sequence of numbers generated from a set of rules. In this case, I used the [Collatz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collatz_conjecture) sequence because it has a decreasing, random-looking pattern, which is a nice feature for plant structures (e.g. the internode distribution on a stem). This sequence is used to define a curve, by mapping sequence elements to segment length, with a random angle between segments. Multiple curves are computed to constitute a node, and multiple nodes to constitute a stem / individual. Further recursion can be used to create populations of multiple individuals, with random or community-dependent features. The main random elements are the initial value of the sequence, and the angle distribution between curve segments. I explained this approach a bit more in details during a talk at an art show, slides are available [here](https://github.com/picasa/slides_code_to_ink). On this series, rather than properly computing hidden line or polygons, I used an external algorithm (bitmap tracing) which had the nice side-effect of reshaping and merging some paths.
